NTM (Nontuberculous Mycobacteria).definition_short: Nontuberculous mycobacteria - bacteria found in water and soil that can cause lung infections
NTM (Nontuberculous Mycobacteria).definition_long: Nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) are bacteria that live naturally in water, soil, and dust. Unlike tuberculosis, NTM is not contagious. These bacteria can cause lung infections, especially in people with damaged airways or weakened immune systems.

MAC (Mycobacterium avium complex).definition_short: Mycobacterium avium complex - the most common type of NTM lung infection
MAC (Mycobacterium avium complex).definition_long: Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is the most common group of NTM bacteria that cause lung infections. It includes two species: M. avium and M. intracellulare. MAC is found in water sources and requires long-term antibiotic treatment.

Bronchiectasis.definition_short: A lung condition where airways are permanently widened and damaged, leading to mucus buildup
Bronchiectasis.definition_long: Bronchiectasis is a chronic lung condition where the airways (bronchial tubes) become permanently widened, scarred, and damaged. This makes it hard to clear mucus, leading to frequent respiratory infections. It often co-occurs with NTM.

M. kansasii.title: M. kansasii
M. kansasii.usage_notes: NTM species; responds better to treatment than MAC
M. kansasii.definition_short: A species of NTM bacteria that generally responds better to treatment than MAC
M. kansasii.definition_long: Mycobacterium kansasii is a type of NTM bacteria that causes lung infections. It typically responds better to antibiotic treatment than MAC and may require shorter treatment duration. Treatment usually includes rifampin, ethambutol, and either isoniazid or a macrolide.

Azithromycin.definition_short: A macrolide antibiotic, one of the Big Three medications for treating MAC lung disease
Azithromycin.definition_long: Azithromycin (brand name Zithromax) is a macrolide antibiotic and one of the three core medications in the 'Big Three' treatment regimen for MAC. Typically taken 3 times per week (Monday, Wednesday, Friday) for nodular disease or daily for cavitary disease. Common side effects include nausea and hearing changes. Patients should have periodic hearing tests.

Ethambutol.definition_short: An antibiotic used in the Big Three; requires regular eye exams due to risk of vision side effects
Ethambutol.definition_long: Ethambutol (brand name Myambutol) is one of the Big Three antibiotics for MAC treatment. It's known for potential vision-related side effects, particularly affecting color vision and visual acuity. Patients must have baseline eye exams before starting and regular monitoring during treatment. Any vision changes should be reported immediately.

Rifampin.definition_short: An antibiotic in the Big Three; causes orange discoloration of body fluids
Rifampin.definition_long: Rifampin (also called rifampicin) is one of the Big Three antibiotics for MAC. It causes harmless orange-red discoloration of urine, sweat, tears, and other body fluids. Can interact with many medications including birth control pills. Some patients switch to rifabutin if rifampin causes side effects.

Big Three.definition_short: The standard first-line treatment for MAC: azithromycin, ethambutol, and rifampin
Big Three.definition_long: The 'Big Three' refers to the standard first-line antibiotic combination for treating MAC lung disease: azithromycin (or clarithromycin), ethambutol, and rifampin (or rifabutin). Patients typically take these three medications daily for at least 12 months after sputum cultures turn negative.

Tree-in-bud.definition_long: Tree-in-bud is a characteristic pattern seen on chest CT scans that looks like small branching trees or buds. It indicates inflammation and mucus plugging in the small airways and is commonly seen in NTM lung disease and bronchiectasis.

search_index.title: AFB (Acid-Fast Bacilli)
search_index.usage_notes: Test that detects mycobacteria

search_index.title: Acapella
search_index.usage_notes: Alternative to Aerobika; comes in different resistances

search_index.title: Aerobika
search_index.usage_notes: Popular handheld airway clearance device

search_index.title: Airway Clearance
search_index.definition_short: Techniques and devices used daily to help clear mucus from lungs
search_index.definition_long: Airway clearance refers to techniques and devices used to help remove mucus from the lungs. For NTM and bronchiectasis patients, this typically includes nebulized saline, devices like Aerobika or vest therapy, and breathing techniques. Done 1-2 times daily as maintenance.
search_index.usage_notes: Essential daily routine for NTM/bronchiectasis patients

search_index.title: Albuterol
search_index.usage_notes: Opens airways; often used before other nebulized treatments

search_index.title: Amikacin
search_index.usage_notes: Can be given IV or inhaled; precursor to Arikayce

search_index.title: Arikayce
search_index.definition_short: An inhaled antibiotic (amikacin liposome) approved for treatment-resistant MAC
search_index.definition_long: Arikayce (amikacin liposome inhalation suspension) is an FDA-approved inhaled antibiotic for treating MAC lung disease that hasn't responded to standard treatment. It's nebulized once daily and added to oral antibiotics. Common side effects include hoarseness and risk of hearing loss.
search_index.usage_notes: FDA-approved for refractory MAC; expensive; requires prior authorization

search_index.title: Aspiration
search_index.usage_notes: Breathing in stomach contents; increases NTM risk

search_index.title: Azithromycin
search_index.definition_short: A macrolide antibiotic, one of the Big Three medications for treating MAC lung disease
search_index.definition_long: Azithromycin (brand name Zithromax) is a macrolide antibiotic and one of the three core medications in the 'Big Three' treatment regimen for MAC. Typically taken 3 times per week (Monday, Wednesday, Friday) for nodular disease or daily for cavitary disease. Common side effects include nausea and hearing changes. Patients should have periodic hearing tests.
search_index.usage_notes: One of the "Big Three" antibiotics for MAC treatment

search_index.title: Big Three
search_index.definition_short: The standard first-line treatment for MAC: azithromycin, ethambutol, and rifampin
search_index.definition_long: The 'Big Three' refers to the standard first-line antibiotic combination for treating MAC lung disease: azithromycin (or clarithromycin), ethambutol, and rifampin (or rifabutin). Patients typically take these three medications daily for at least 12 months after sputum cultures turn negative.
search_index.usage_notes: Standard first-line treatment for MAC

search_index.title: Biofilm
search_index.usage_notes: Layer of bacteria on surfaces; difficult to eliminate; key to NTM persistence in water

search_index.title: Bronchiectasis
search_index.definition_short: A lung condition where airways are permanently widened and damaged, leading to mucus buildup
search_index.definition_long: Bronchiectasis is a chronic lung condition where the airways (bronchial tubes) become permanently widened, scarred, and damaged. This makes it hard to clear mucus, leading to frequent respiratory infections. It often co-occurs with NTM.
search_index.usage_notes: Often co-occurs with NTM; abbreviated as "BE" by experienced patients

search_index.title: Bronchoscopy
search_index.usage_notes: Invasive procedure to collect samples from lungs

search_index.title: CT Scan
search_index.usage_notes: Primary imaging test for monitoring NTM/bronchiectasis

search_index.title: Cavitary MAC
search_index.usage_notes: More severe form; requires 7 days/week treatment; worse prognosis

search_index.title: Cavities
search_index.usage_notes: Hollow areas in lung tissue; concerning finding

search_index.title: Cefoxitin
search_index.usage_notes: IV antibiotic sometimes used for M. abscessus

search_index.title: Chest Percussion
search_index.usage_notes: Manual or mechanical tapping on chest to loosen mucus

search_index.title: Clarithromycin
search_index.usage_notes: Alternative to azithromycin in Big Three regimen

search_index.title: Clofazimine
search_index.usage_notes: Causes skin discoloration (orange/red/brown)

search_index.title: Colonization
search_index.usage_notes: Bacteria present but not causing active disease

search_index.title: Culture Conversion
search_index.definition_short: When sputum cultures turn negative after being positive for NTM
search_index.definition_long: Culture conversion means achieving three consecutive monthly negative sputum cultures after previously testing positive for NTM. This is the primary goal of treatment and indicates the antibiotics are working. Treatment continues for 12 months after conversion.
search_index.usage_notes: Goal of treatment; three consecutive negative monthly cultures required

search_index.title: Cystic Fibrosis
search_index.usage_notes: Genetic condition with high NTM risk

search_index.title: Ethambutol
search_index.definition_short: An antibiotic used in the Big Three; requires regular eye exams due to risk of vision side effects
search_index.definition_long: Ethambutol (brand name Myambutol) is one of the Big Three antibiotics for MAC treatment. It's known for potential vision-related side effects, particularly affecting color vision and visual acuity. Patients must have baseline eye exams before starting and regular monitoring during treatment. Any vision changes should be reported immediately.
search_index.usage_notes: One of the "Big Three" antibiotics; known for vision side effects; requires regular eye exams

search_index.title: Exacerbation
search_index.usage_notes: Worsening of symptoms (increased cough, sputum, fever, fatigue)

search_index.title: FEV1 (Forced Expiratory Volume)
search_index.usage_notes: Key metric in pulmonary function tests

search_index.title: FVC (Forced Vital Capacity)
search_index.usage_notes: Measures total amount of air exhaled

search_index.title: GERD
search_index.usage_notes: Risk factor for NTM; can cause aspiration

search_index.title: Ground Glass Opacities
search_index.usage_notes: Hazy areas on CT; can indicate hypersensitivity pneumonitis from Arikayce

search_index.title: HEPA Filter
search_index.usage_notes: Can reduce airborne particles; some patients use for prevention

search_index.title: HRCT
search_index.usage_notes: More detailed than regular CT; gold standard for bronchiectasis

search_index.title: Hemoptysis
search_index.usage_notes: Serious symptom requiring medical attention

search_index.title: Huff Cough
search_index.usage_notes: Breathing technique to help expel mucus; less tiring than regular coughing

search_index.title: Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis
search_index.usage_notes: Allergic lung reaction; rare but serious complication of Arikayce

search_index.title: Hypertonic Saline
search_index.usage_notes: Stronger concentration than normal saline (3% or 7%); helps mobilize mucus

search_index.title: IV Antibiotics
search_index.usage_notes: Used for severe or resistant NTM; requires IV access or PICC line

search_index.title: Imipenem
search_index.usage_notes: IV carbapenem antibiotic for resistant NTM

search_index.title: Immunocompromised
search_index.usage_notes: Reduced immune function increases NTM susceptibility

search_index.title: Infiltrates
search_index.usage_notes: Areas of inflammation or infection on imaging

search_index.title: Lady Windermere Syndrome
search_index.usage_notes: Classic NTM pattern in older women; right middle lobe and lingula involvement

search_index.title: Linezolid
search_index.usage_notes: Used for resistant NTM; requires monitoring for side effects (neuropathy, bone marrow suppression)

search_index.title: Lingula
search_index.usage_notes: Left-sided equivalent of right middle lobe; common NTM site

search_index.title: M. abscessus (Mycobacterium abscessus)
search_index.usage_notes: More difficult to treat than MAC

search_index.title: M. chelonae
search_index.usage_notes: Rapidly growing mycobacterium; similar to M. abscessus

search_index.title: M. kansasii
search_index.definition_short: A species of NTM bacteria that generally responds better to treatment than MAC
search_index.definition_long: Mycobacterium kansasii is a type of NTM bacteria that causes lung infections. It typically responds better to antibiotic treatment than MAC and may require shorter treatment duration. Treatment usually includes rifampin, ethambutol, and either isoniazid or a macrolide.
search_index.usage_notes: NTM species; responds better to treatment than MAC

search_index.title: M. simiae
search_index.usage_notes: Less common NTM species; can be present without requiring treatment

search_index.title: MAC (Mycobacterium avium complex)
search_index.definition_short: Mycobacterium avium complex - the most common type of NTM lung infection
search_index.definition_long: Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is the most common group of NTM bacteria that cause lung infections. It includes two species: M. avium and M. intracellulare. MAC is found in water sources and requires long-term antibiotic treatment.
search_index.usage_notes: Most common type of NTM infection discussed in forum

search_index.title: NTM (Nontuberculous Mycobacteria)
search_index.definition_short: Nontuberculous mycobacteria - bacteria found in water and soil that can cause lung infections
search_index.definition_long: Nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) are bacteria that live naturally in water, soil, and dust. Unlike tuberculosis, NTM is not contagious. These bacteria can cause lung infections, especially in people with damaged airways or weakened immune systems.
search_index.usage_notes: NTM is the most common abbreviation in patient discussions

search_index.title: Nebulizer
search_index.usage_notes: Device that converts liquid medication to mist; common brands include PARI, Volara

search_index.title: Neuropathy
search_index.usage_notes: Nerve damage from antibiotics; can cause numbness, tingling, pain

search_index.title: Nodular MAC
search_index.usage_notes: Most common form; often treated 3x/week; better prognosis than cavitary

search_index.title: Nodules
search_index.usage_notes: Small round spots seen on CT scans

search_index.title: Omadacycline
search_index.usage_notes: Newer tetracycline antibiotic; can be oral or IV

search_index.title: Ototoxicity
search_index.usage_notes: Damage to inner ear from antibiotics; can be permanent

search_index.title: PFT (Pulmonary Function Test)
search_index.usage_notes: Measures lung capacity and function

search_index.title: PICC Line
search_index.usage_notes: Catheter for long-term IV antibiotic administration

search_index.title: Postural Drainage
search_index.usage_notes: Using gravity positions to help mucus drain from lungs

search_index.title: Probiotics
search_index.usage_notes: Taken to prevent/reduce diarrhea from antibiotics; space 6 hours from antibiotics

search_index.title: Pseudomonas
search_index.usage_notes: Common co-infection in bronchiectasis patients

search_index.title: Refractory MAC
search_index.usage_notes: MAC that doesn't respond to standard treatment

search_index.title: Rifabutin
search_index.usage_notes: Alternative to rifampin; may have fewer side effects

search_index.title: Rifampin
search_index.definition_short: An antibiotic in the Big Three; causes orange discoloration of body fluids
search_index.definition_long: Rifampin (also called rifampicin) is one of the Big Three antibiotics for MAC. It causes harmless orange-red discoloration of urine, sweat, tears, and other body fluids. Can interact with many medications including birth control pills. Some patients switch to rifabutin if rifampin causes side effects.
search_index.usage_notes: One of the "Big Three"; causes orange discoloration of bodily fluids

search_index.title: Right Middle Lobe
search_index.usage_notes: Common site for NTM infection in women

search_index.title: Saline
search_index.usage_notes: Used to help loosen mucus; normal saline is 0.9%

search_index.title: Showerhead Cleaning
search_index.usage_notes: Monthly 30-minute vinegar soak recommended to prevent biofilm

search_index.title: Sputum
search_index.usage_notes: Critical for diagnostic testing

search_index.title: Sputum Culture
search_index.usage_notes: Used to diagnose and monitor NTM; takes 6-8 weeks for results

search_index.title: Tigecycline
search_index.usage_notes: IV antibiotic for severe/resistant cases

search_index.title: Tobramycin
search_index.usage_notes: Inhaled antibiotic often used for pseudomonas

search_index.title: Tree-in-bud
search_index.definition_short: A CT scan pattern showing small branching spots, typical of NTM and bronchiectasis
search_index.definition_long: Tree-in-bud is a characteristic pattern seen on chest CT scans that looks like small branching trees or buds. It indicates inflammation and mucus plugging in the small airways and is commonly seen in NTM lung disease and bronchiectasis.
search_index.usage_notes: Classic CT finding in NTM lung disease

search_index.title: Upper Lobe Disease
search_index.usage_notes: Disease in upper parts of lungs; associated with cavitary MAC

search_index.title: Vest
search_index.usage_notes: Motorized vest that vibrates chest to loosen mucus

search_index.title: Vision Changes
search_index.usage_notes: Ethambutol can cause vision problems; requires regular eye exams

search_index.title: Watch and Wait
search_index.usage_notes: Approach for asymptomatic patients; regular monitoring without antibiotics

search_index.title: Water Heater Temperature
search_index.usage_notes: Raising to 130°F kills NTM; takes 8-10 days to clear plumbing system
